analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: received July 12, 2016; revised October 28, 2016; accepted January 1, 2017.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: By employing the finite-time control method, the consensus control algorithm for higher-order multiagent systems is designed in this paper. Under a neighbor-based rule, a higherorder finite-time consensus algorithm is explicitly constructed, which only uses local information. The finite-time consensus control algorithm can guarantee that the state consensus is achieved in a finite time. In addition, for multiagent systems having a leader-following structure, the consensus algorithm is also designed. Finally, two examples are presented to show the effectiveness.
which demands the agreement of all agents (processes) on a common value (also called consensus state) through an appropriate algorithm/protocol.

To date, the consensus problem has gained tremendous progress in various forms. A theoretical framework about firstorder consensus algorithm was presented in [21] and [22]. Later, many kinds of second-order consensus algorithms were introduced, in [23]- [29], to name just a few. When the agent is described by a nonlinear model, many nonlinear consensus algorithms were also proposed, e.g., formation cooperative control of nonholonomic robots [12], attitude synchronization control of multiple rigid spacecraft [14], etc. Note that all these results focus on lower-dimensional multiagent systems. When the agent has a higher-order dynamics, corresponding consensus algorithms were also given [30]- [35].

The convergence rate is an important issue. The majority of existing results about consensus algorithms only guarantee asymptotic convergence. In a recent attempt to obtain a faster convergence speed, the works [36]- [38] introduced and developed the finite-time control method. It is more desirable if all the agents' states reach consensus in a finite time, i.e., finite-time consensus. In addition, the finite-time stable system shows the better ability of disturbance rejection [36], [39]. Considering such advantages, for linear multiagent systems, some first/second-order finite-time consensus algorithms were proposed in [40]- [48]. Also, for nonlinear multiagent systems, e.g., attitude system of rigid spacecraft, several finite-time attitude synchronization algorithms were given in [49] and [50].

It should be pointed out that all the aforementioned papers on finite-time consensus algorithms focus on multiagent systems which has a lower-order dynamics. For higher-order multiagent systems, the finite-time consensus problem is more challenging. Note that in [37] and [38], some methods about the design of higher-order finite-time controller for single system were proposed. However, it is well-known that the extension from single system to multiple systems is not trivial, where the main challenging lies in that each agent only uses the local information in the case with multiple systems. Although the work [51] designed a higher-order finite-time consensus algorithm, only leaderless case was considered. To this end, this paper provides a new constructive method to design higher-order finite-time consensus algorithms for both cases of leaderless and leaderfollowing. Specifically, by utilizing the technique of adding a power integrator [52], a neighbor-based distributed higherorder finite-time consensus algorithm is explicitly presented step by step. A Lyapunov function is recursively constructed to prove the finite-time convergence and the finite convergent time is also estimated. Under the proposed consensus algorithm, rigorous proof shows that the state finite-time consensus is reached. For leader-following multiagent systems, by a similar design method, a higher-order finite-time consensus tracking algorithm is also developed. If the leader is static, all the followers' output can reach the leader's output in a finite time. If the leader is dynamic, all the followers' output can enter to a neighborhood of the leader's output in a finite time. The main contribution of this paper are two aspects. 1) A solution is provided to solve the finite-time consensus problem for higher-order linear multiagent systems and a neighbor-based distributed higher-order finite-time consensus algorithm is explicitly constructed step by step. 2) For leader-following multiagent systems, a distributed higher-order finite-time consensus tracking algorithm is also proposed, which does not require the leader's velocity information. It means that this algorithm has a wide application range, e.g., the case with unmeasurable leader's velocity as that [26].

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES A. Problem Formulation
div.p: The consensus problem for higher-order multiagent systems is considered. As in [31], assume that there are m agents and the system model of the ith agent is
div.formula: ẋi,1 = x i,2 ẋi,2 = x i,3 . . . ẋi,n = u i y i = x i,1 i ∈(1)
div.p: where x i,1 , . . . , x i,n are the system states, y i is the system output, u i is the controller, called protocol. Remark 1: Note that here although only a chain of n integrators [i.e., system (1)] is considered, it is wellknown that any single-input, single-output (SISO) controllable linear system can be transformed into the form of
div.formula: ẋi,j = x i,j+1 , j = 1, . . . , n -1 ẋi,n = -a 1 x i,1 -a 2 x i,2 -• • • -a n x i,n + u i := U i .
div.p: Clearly, if the case in this paper [i.e., chained integrators system (1)] is solvable, the case with an SISO controllable linear system is also solvable.

The objective here is to design a consensus algorithm/protocol for multiagent system (1) such that the state consensus can be achieved in a finite time. From a mathematical viewpoint, the finite-time consensus requires ∀i, j ∈
div.formula: lim t→T x i (t) -x j (t) = 0 and x i (t) -x j (t) = 0, ∀t ≥ T (2)
div.p: where T is a finite time.

The challenge in the consensus protocol design is that each agent can only use the information of itself and the neighbors. In fact, consensus protocol based on such a neighboring rule has become a common design method.

div.head: B. Graph Theory and Some Lemmas
div.p: Consider m agents and assume that the communication among m agents is denoted by an undirected graph G = {V, E, A}, where V = {v i , i = 1, . . . , m} is the set of vertices, E ⊆ V × V is the set of edges and A = [a ij ] ∈ R m×m is the weighted adjacency matrix of the graph G. Let = {1, . . . , m}. If there is an edge between agent i and agent j, i.e., (v i , v j ) ∈ E, then a ij = a ji > 0, otherwise a ij = a ji = 0. In addition, a ii = 0 for all i ∈ . The neighbors of node v i is represented by
div.formula: N i = {v j : (v i , v j ) ∈ E}. Define the out-degree of node v i as deg out (v i ) = d i = m j=1 a ij = j∈N i a ij . The degree matrix of the digraph G is D = diag{d 1 , . . . , d m } and the Laplacian matrix of digraph G is L = D -A.
div.p: The graph G is connected if for any two nodes there is a path.
Lemma 1 [36]:
div.formula: For system ẋ = f (x), f (0) = 0, x ∈ R n(3)
div.p: where f (•) : R n → R n is a continuous function, if there is a positive definite continuous function V(x) : U → R, such that V(x) + c(V(x)) α ≤ 0, where c > 0 and α ∈ (0, 1), V(x) reaches 0 in a finite time. The finite convergent time T satisfies T ≤ (V(x(0)) 1-α /c(1 -α)).
Lemma 2 [52]: If 0 < q = q 1 /q 2 ≤ 1, where q 1 > 0, q 2 > 0 are positive odd integers, then |x qy q | ≤ 2 1-q |x -y| q .
Lemma 3 [52]: For any c > 0, d > 0, γ > 0
div.formula: |x| c |y| d ≤ c c + d γ |x| c+d + d c + d γ -c/d |y| c+d , ∀x, y ∈ R.
div.p: Lemma 4 [53]: For any
Lemma 5 [22]: The Laplacian matrix L of undirected connected graph G satisfies:
div.formula: 1) x T Lx = (1/2) m i,j=1 a ij (x i -x j ) 2 = (1/2) m i=1 j∈N i a ij (x i - x j ) 2 for any x = [x 1 , . . . , x m ] T ∈ R m ; 2) if the eigenvalues of L are 0, λ 2 , . . . , λ m , satisfying 0 ≤ λ 2 ≤ • • • ≤ λ m , the second smallest eigenvalue λ 2 > 0. In addition, λ 2 = min x =0,1 T x=0 (x T Lx/x T x). That is, if 1 T x = 0, where 1 = [1, . . . , 1] T , then x T Lx ≥ λ 2 x T x.

div.head: III. FINITE-TIME CONSENSUS FOR LEADERLESS
div.p: MULTIAGENT SYSTEM For the leaderless multiagent system (1), a higher-order finite-time consensus protocol is designed in this section.

Since τ < 0, by Lemma 1, V n approaches zero in a finite time. It means that there is a time
div.formula: T ≤ (V n (0) -τ/2 /(-τ/2)ρ -(2+τ/2) ) < +∞, such that V n ≡ 0, ∀t ≥ T. It means that V 1 (t) ≡ 0, ∀t ≥ T. By the definition of V 1 , V 1 (t) = 0 implies that x i,1 = x j,1
div.p: , ∀i, j ∈ . Then, from system (1), for l = 2, . . . , n, one has x i,l = x j,l , ∀i, j ∈ . With this fact, it is concluded that the state consensus is achieved in a finite time.

Remark 2: Based on the Lyapunov function (36), it can be found that under the proposed finite-time consensus algorithm (5), the final steady state for the leaderless multiagent systems (1) is x i,1 → x j,1 and x i,m → 0, m = 2, . . . , n, i.e., the final consensus state is a static point. Actually, as shown that in [24], by using the matrix L+B instead of the matrix L in the step 1, the result in this section can be directly used to solve the consensus tracking problem with a static leader which will be presented in the next section. However, different from [24], the agent considered in this paper has a higher-order dynamics and the proposed algorithm in this paper can guarantee that the convergence is finite-time convergent.

div.head: IV. FINITE-TIME CONSENSUS FOR LEADER-FOLLOWING
div.p: MULTIAGENT SYSTEMS In the previous section, a higher-order consensus algorithm is designed for leaderless multiagent systems, where the final consensus states are not explicitly determined. In some cases, it is desirable that all the agents not only achieve state consensus, but also reach a predesired consensus state (e.g., reference trajectory). To this end, an available method is to add a leader agent to the multiagent system (i.e., to form a leader-following multiagent system) such that all the agents (called follower agents) can track and follow it.

One challenging problem in leader-following multiagent systems is when the leader's information is available only to a subset of the follower agents. Notationally, if the ith (i ∈ ) follower agent can obtain the leader's information,
div.formula: then b i > 0, otherwise, b i = 0. Define B = diag{b 1 , . . . , b m }.
div.p: As in [25] and [45], an assumption is first needed.

Assumption 1: For the leader-following multiagent system (1) with a leader, the graph G for the followers is connected and there is at least one directed edge from a certain follower to the leader, i.e., B = 0, at each time.
For the leader agent, there are two cases: one is a static leader, and the other is a dynamic leader. Assume that the leader's output is its position, y r .

div.head: A. Static Leader
div.p: Consider the case of a static leader, that is, ẏr ≡ 0. Theorem 2: For the leader-following multiagent system (1) with a stationary leader whose output is y r , if Assumption 1 holds and u i is designed as
div.formula: u i = -β n ⎡ ⎣ x 1 rn i,n + β 1 rn n-1 ⎡ ⎣ x 1 r n-1 i,n-1 + • • • + β 1 r 3 2 ⎡ ⎣ x 1 r 2 i,2 + β 1 r 2 1 ⎡ ⎣ j∈N i a ij x i,1 -x j,1 + b i (y i -y r ) ⎤ ⎦ ⎤ ⎦ • • • ⎤ ⎦ ⎤ ⎦ r n +τ i ∈ (42
div.p: where β i , i = 1, . . . , n, are appropriate constant gains, then the outputs of all the agents achieve a consensus in a finite time and the consensus output is y r , i.e., y i → y r in a finite time for all i ∈ . Proof: From the proofs of Theorems 1 and 3, the proof can be easily derived, so it is omitted.

div.head: B. Dynamic Leader
div.p: Consider the case of a dynamic leader. Here, as in [26], it is assumed that the dynamic leader has an unknown velocity, i.e., ẏr is unknown. In this case, there is usually a tracking error between the leader and any follower's output. The following assumption on the leader's output is imposed.
Assumption 2: There are known constants M 1 and M 2 such that

Since is a level set of a Lyapunov function, it is an invariant set, that is, once x(t) ∈ then it will stay there forever.

div.p: Since δ is an arbitrary constant, the proof can be completed.

Remark 3: It should be pointed out that there is no restrictions on the second and higher order derivatives of y r , which is also a main difference/property of the proposed result in this paper by comparing with the existing results. It certainly enlarges the family of time-varying reference signals (i.e., leader's trajectory) to be tracked. For example, when the leader's velocity is unmeasurable/unavailable in practice as discussed in [26], the proposed result (i.e., Section IV-B) in this paper can deal with it. The main reason why we do not require any restrictions is that the proposed algorithm (42) and the proof of Theorem 3 do not need/use any information of the second and higher order derivatives of y r .

Remark 4: Note that the estimate of the tracking error is not only related to the control gains but also to the other parameter τ which is related to the fractional powers in the finite-time controller. So, in practice, in order to reduce the tracking error, one can simultaneously regulate these two kinds of parameters.

div.head: V. NUMERICAL EXAMPLES AND SIMULATIONS
div.p: Example 1: A third-order multiagent system (1) is considered, which is described by

Fig. 1 shows the communication topology, which is an undirected connected graph. Hence, by Theorem 1, a finite-time consensus algorithm can be constructed. For instance, with τ = -2/9, the third-order finite-time consensus control algorithm is obtained as Example 2: Consider a third-order leader-following multiagent system with four follower agents described by (73) and a dynamic leader whose output is y r = sin(0.2t). Fig. 4 shows the communication topology. By Theorem 3, one can design a finite-time consensus control algorithm such that all the followers's outputs reach a neighborhood of the leader's output in a finite time. For instance, with τ = -2/9, the finite-time consensus tracking control algorithm is obtained as

with appropriate gains β 1 , β 2 , and β 3 . Fig. 5 gives the response curves of the tracking error, where the gains are chosen as β 1 = 1.5, β 2 = 2, and β 3 = 4, and initial condition are chosen randomly. VI. CONCLUSION The finite-time consensus problem for a class of higherorder multiagent systems has been investigated. Two different structure multiagent systems have been considered, one is leaderless and the other one is leader-following. First, for the leaderless multiagent systems, using the method of adding a power integrator, a higher-order finite-time consensus algorithm has been explicitly constructed step by step, which can guarantee that the consensus of systems' states can be reached in a finite time. Then, for the leader-following multiagent systems, a higher-order finite-time consensus tracking algorithm has also been proposed. Rigorous proofs have shown that if the leader is static, then all the follows can track the leader in a finite time, if the leader is dynamic, all the follows can reach arbitrarily small neighborhood of the leader in a finite time. Future work includes how to extend the proposed method to nonlinear multiagent systems.

div.head: APPENDIX PROOF OF PROPOSITION 1
div.p: The proof is done based on an inductive argument. First of all, for k = 2, it follows from (17) that there is a constant μ 2 ≥ 0 such that:
div.formula: d -x i,2 * 1/r 2 dt ≤ μ 2 m l=1 ξ l,2 r 2 + ξ l,1 r 2 . (76
div.p: Assume the relation ( 29) holds for step k -1. Then, it will be shown that this relation also holds for step k. Note that
div.formula: d -x i,k * 1/r k dt = β i,k-1 1/r k ξi,k-1 . (77
div.p: Since
div.formula: ξ i,k-1 = x 1/r k-1 i,k-1 -x * i,k-1 1/r k-1 , one has ξi,k-1 = x 1/r k-1 -1 i,k-1 ẋi,k-1 + d -x * i,k-1 1/r k-1 dt . (78
div.p: Using Lemma 3 leads to
div.formula: x 1/r k-1 -1 i,k-1 ẋi,k-1 = x 1/r k-1 -1 i,k-1 x i,k = x 1/r k-1 i,k-1 1-r k-1 x 1/r k i,k r k ≤ 1 -r k-1 1 + τ x i,k-1 1+τ r k-1 + r k 1 + τ x i,k 1+τ r k . (79
div.p: With this inequality and by a similar proof to (15), there is dk > 0 such that
div.formula: x 1/r k-1 -1 i,k-1 ẋi,k-1 ≤ dk ξ i,k-2 1+τ + ξ i,k-1 1+τ + ξ i,k 1+τ .
div.p: (80) Substituting ( 80) into (78), and according to the inductive assumption, one concludes that there is a constant μ k > 0 such that
div.formula: d -x i,k * 1/r k dt ≤ μ k ⎛ ⎝ k j=1 ξ i,j 1+τ + m l=1 ξ l,2 1+τ + ξ l,1 1+τ ⎞ ⎠ . (81)

div.p: This work was supported in part by the Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61673153, Grant 61304007, and Grant 61673104, in part by the Hong Kong GRF Grant under Grant CityU11201414, in part by the Chung-Ying Tang Foundation, in part by the Scientific Research and Development Funds of the Hefei University of Technology under Grant JZ2016HGXJ0023, and in part by the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of China under Grant 2242016K41030. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor Y.-J.

Haibo Du (M'12) received the B.Sc. degree in mathematics from Anhui Normal University, Wuhu, China, in 2004, and the Ph.D. degree in automatic control from Southeast University, Nanjing, China, in 2012.

He is currently an Associate Professor with the School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, China. His current research interests include nonlinear system control, cooperative control of distributed multiagent systems, and spacecraft attitude control.
Guanghui Wen (S'11-M'13) received the Ph.D. degree in mechanical systems and control from Peking University, Beijing, China, in 2012.

He is currently an Associate Professor with the Department of Mathematics, Southeast University, Nanjing, China. He held several visiting positions in Australia, China, and Qatar. His current research interests include cooperative control of multiagent systems, analysis and synthesis of complex networks, cyber-physical systems, and robust control.
